												This is a terrible game. Absolutely awful. I can't believe I finished it.I like retro games. I have a lot of nostalgia for SNES era RPGs. But those games relied on their stories to make up for their lack of expressive graphics. Whereas here the art and sound are maybe the only positives for Labyronia. The music was solid. The visuals are decent. And the special effects can be quite good.But the story. The writing. The game system. The grinding. The backtracking. The mazes. All abysmal.There's no plot. Go collect four crystals. Gee, never seen that before.Despite the fact that this is a party game with up to three characters for you to play as you'll have only a single character for the first 95% of the game. The second and third come in time for the final dungeon. That's it.Getting to the end is the biggest chore. You have to grind in order to move forward. At least 2-3 hours of my 12 hour playthrough was grinding. It's bad planning. You can do the math for the system so that's not required.Even figuring out where to go next is basically impossible. The overworld does not have a lot of clues. There is no journal, no list of quests or an objective. That would be fine if the way to move forward made any sort of logical sense, but it doesn't.The dungeon/labyrinth design is the worst part of it all. They infinitely wrap around on themselves, so you have no idea where you're oriented within one. I spent several hours just wandering around, lost. This is a stupid problem to have in a game. There's no reason for it. Simply putting an edge on the map and not making them wrap would've helped immensely, and been way more believable physically.On top of that, there's no faster form of travel than walking until the very end. And of course, you have to do massive amounts of backtracking in order to move forward. But this is not explicitly stated anywhere. Finding the key items needed to progress is a futile endeavor. You can spend many many hours with no idea what you're supposed to do. Your only recourse is to revisit every location. It's beyond frustrating.I can't believe this game made it through play testing as designed. I would've sent it back to the drawing board.

												Okay !!! After quite an extensive run and being stuck at the moment ( and refusing any outside help). I thought it might eb a good idea to write a review of this game as a sort of catharsis after hat I went through.First thing first, if I had to describe Labyronia, I'll say that the game lives up to its namesake, because this is a god damn MAZE !!! No really, I've never felt that lost in a game, you'll spend hour trying to figure out the exit of an area with no reliable way to keep track on where you're going. You'll bash your head in frustration on your keyboard and pray David Bowie to get you out of here, but the only thing you'll get will be an ankward glare from your roommate. To make the matter worse, this game really likes backtracking ... and it'll make sure that you must return multiple time in the same location to get in a SPECIFIC area (odds are that you'll find it randomly most of the time). Devs say they took inspiration from pokemon for their game. That statement is quite true, type advantage is key for winning battles in this game. They even brought you memorable feature from Pokemon such as "the run in a cave without Flash with Zubats everywhere". Unfortunately, no escape rope or dig, which I think would have been great features in this game considering the lenght of certain dungeons without a shortcut to the exit when done ( from what I've seen you get a blimp later on in the game, but you'll have to get through 8 hours of walking to get that reward, and I hope you can actualy use it to fast travel the world map).An other thing regarding the battle system and which pained me is that it seems that some fights are neraly impossible without a specific item or spell. And I'm not talking about quest item or plot spell ! No I'm taling about easely missable features that will bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥later if you don't have them for the battle. A sound exemple will be for the Chimera, if you go unprepared, you'll find that this fight is impossible no matter how much you try because of one ability that prevent your character from doing anything during the fight (you're bloody petrify). Of course there is only one way to go around that ability, but it's NOT in the dungeon ! No it's some special boots that make you immune to stunt and petrify ailments and are sold by only one merchant that happened to be on the other side from where you standing, and that you came by 2 hours ago !!! Needless to say, the reason if I'm currently stuck in the game is because I just happened to bump into another creature like that; and I can't defeat it because somehow I missed again the missable item that I need to beat it ( and it's not even a boss !! ) .Other than that, I'll say battle are pretty challenging and rewarding when you do have the key elements needed, ennemies actions are not randomize but follow a pattern of actions that they repeat over and over in the same order, alloing you to play around these actions to take minimal damages from punishing blow while destroying your opponent when his guard is open.Now regarding the story, so far there is not much exposition, which is a good thing ! The story is your to discover through books and dialogues which are quite extensive and well written ( despite some being forced and cringe worthy, trust me you'll understand me when you get to the desert level). Unfortunately I've failed so far to find the main character interesting ( granted I don't find him annoying and it's kind of reflreshing to have a mature man for a lead character), I feel like the dev were focusing to much on his backstory ( which is great)  to give him actual character traits, so far none that he'd displayed stroke me as memorable and some were kind of contradicting themselve ... I don't have much to say about the supportive cast considering I've not seen much of them for now, just that I recruited my first party member after 7 hours of gameplay which is kinda long, and it seems like you have to a GLORIOUS amount of backtracking in past areas if you want to unlock new power for them (and again there is no way to tell if any of them is going to prove MANDATORY in the future).Now despite, all the backlashes, I still don't hate this game, it's like dark souls playing with your nerves and pushing you to the limit of self-destruction. It's quite remarkable that I'm still able to enjoy a game that frustrating. To be honest, the game is quite well made for an RPG Maker game. Sure it doesn't go overboard and use it's own sprite our illustration (hell even that thumbnail for the game lokks like vergil from Dmc ) but it's still quite charming with the world their proposing.To top it off, the game is not expensive at all, you'll have a run for your money so no reason for not buying it.

												I would definitely recommend Labyronia, it is not without issues but these are far outweighed by its successes. The combat, world, and addiction to levelling your character are all very solid. Reminding me of Mystic Quest(one of the old FF games, renamed for some reason... I think). So far I've yet to pick up any companions but there is space for two by the look of it, will be nice when I finally get one. Much of the combat and movement around the world feels refreshing fast compared to the old games of this type, falling somewhere in between those and Half minute Hero. Far less random encounters hindering your progress and far less long battles for little XP reward, all plus points in my view.The controls are a little bit counter intuitive when played with an Xbox 360 pad, walking done via the left thumb stick and the menu's etc done via the D-Pad. You get used to this quickly and in some ways it actually adds to the retro feel but I would like the option of doing it all on one.The enemies lack animation, though all magics and attacks have nice effects representing them, the werewolf warp effect being one to avoid if you have a problem with strobes. For £2 or less this is to be expected, asset creation is extremely time intensive and every frame of animation pretty much doubles the load, hopefully enough people will buy this to give them both the incentive and the capital to address this in future releases.All in all Labyronia is well worth the asking price for anyone wanting a solid slice of retro style JRPG action!

Labyrinths and a story that surprisesEnter a realm in which mortals played gods, and ultimately failed.Graphics: Ø The graphics aren't surprising, and they are standard - but they are even in their "enlarged" state not ugly and not unsightly.Sound: Ø Quite standard fare for a RPGMaker game. Nothing outstanding, but also nothing too annoying.Playability: + The game has some traps laid out, but those actually make the game work perfect in all other areas. The traps are, spots were a low level character can get killed too easily... so take care, and play through the game. I encountered no bugs... some minor typos and a game that ran smoothly and without even once crashing - and I tried hard to get it crashing... No chance at this. You can't save everywhere in the game which actually isn't bad at all. And encounters are often visible on the maps (only not on the world map).Genre Values:Story: ++ You play Arres a Battlemage with no history at all, and as shrouded as your history is your future and your abilities. You start off trying to know more about your surroundings, and you learn about the monsters invading all the lands - and about the labyrinths which were created by the four elemental gods. The story is well executed, not too nosy and you choose the pace in which you will do your duties. Leveling: + You don't gain powers automatically by rising up a level or by just grinding enough monsters to gather EP's you have to search and look for your powers and it is easy to lose track of powers or even imagine what powers there are in the game for you. This is good, since some spells open up new tactics and new possibilities to get your foes more readily vanquished.Immersion: + Though the game has simple graphics, you can lose yourself in the game. I started to play it and suddenly five hours were gone - most of this effect is derived from the nice story of the game. You just want to know what is your next step, where to go next - why are the people of one city so damn aloof, while in another town you are taken in with a lot of respect. The story uncovers over time your own story, and this makes the game a nice experience. Even grinding is by far not as enervating as you might expect.Overall Rating: 5 + Alone on this I can say that I was positively surprised by the game, first it's under one buck to buy the game. Depending on how forced you play it, you might solve the game in between 10 to 20 hours, a lot of tripple A games with a lot of fancy graphics but a bad storyline offer less to a much higher price, or spread their contents over several editions of the game. The game isn't the invention of the tyre, but it is decent, nice to play and offering some neat entertainment.Value for Money: High at 0,99 The game offers at least 10 hours of game time, a good story and stable gameplay, all this for a really low price. Recommended, especially for JRPG Fans and RPG Fans in general.As I said, the gamedeveloper didn't invent the tyre new, but he tried to deliver a game that runs without killing your time in waste. The only thing that troubled me was the story between Arres and Ann... Huh? You wan't to know? Buy the game... NOW... 												Wanted to like this game, but I found myself completely unable to get into it. Most of the flaws I hit in my short attempt to play were all minor things... but there's just so many small things that they added up. -Remapping the controls is confusing. There's no actual "Options" menu on the main screen (which is baffling to me), so you need to know to hit F1 to remap. And once you do get into it, you find that the keyboard has multiple keys mapped to the same letter, all which seem to be based off the old Sega Genesis Turbo controllers.-Using a controller (at least a X-box one) is awkward. You use the control stick to move, but you can't use it to select options in menus, so you have to constantly swap between D-pad and the stick. Button options also felt odd, and took a couple remapping attempts to feel comfortable for me.-The game starts with a scroll of text that's basically: Monsters wrecked the world. Humanity wussed out. Mages fought and lost. And then you find yourself playing as some guy who wakes up and decides he's going to solve the problem 50-years after it started. But you have no idea who he is, other than he "knows magic". And by "knows magic" I mean he has a heal and that's it. But they give the impression shortly in that you're supposed to be some super well known battle-mage.-Monsters go from being your difficulty level (40ish dmg a hit) to well outside your ability (300+ dmg a hit) with no real signal. You'll walk half a screen away from a easy battle to find yourself getting bashed in the face and hoping to get away.-Edit-Gave it a bit more time (3 hours) hoping something would change. All it's done is let me find more flaws and lessen my opinion even more.-Area maps are, for lack of a better word, round. What I mean by this is you walk into a forest and there is a sign there to tell you it's the entrance. Great! You then decide to go left... and left some more. You end up back at the entrance. Same with if you head up, down, right, doesnt matter. If you head in 1 direction, you wrap around and end up back where you started. And given that theres no map key, you find exploring becomes more of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥than the adventure it should be. It's also completely illogical.-Mob/debuff balance doesnt exist. There are debuff combos that will lock you out of the ability to act and, if RNG is against you, you can go from 100% to dead without being able to attack. And not even against overly strong monsters either. It happened to me against mobs that I had killed in 2 swings in the encounter right before.-The "key items" have no story presence. The goal of the game as far as I can tell at this point, seems to be based around collecting 4 elemental cores. So you would think these cores are hugely important to the world, right? Wrong. The first core has a Guard blocking you way that wont move until you do a quest for the town's leader. You finish the quest and get a letter giving you permission to go anywhere in the city. You use it to pry the god damn gem from the monument in the center of town and walk away without anyone caring (except 1 random NPC who seems VERY nervous about what he saw). And it isnt even like a "Hey you helped our leader, take this very important gem as our thank you!". You do the quest for the leader and they tell you to get the hell away from them and not come back.-3 hours into the game... still no party members. Not even temporary ones. -3 hours into the game... still no backstory on the hero. No plot points, no foreshadowing, nothing.-3 hours into the game... still no STORYLINE. At all. There's no explaination (aside from a 2 second "Guess I'll save the world since no one else can" at the VERY start) on why you're doing what you're doing, or why no one else is fighting. No explaination on why if the world is filled with this powerful destruction causing monsters that theres little villages everywhere without walls or soldiers or graveyards.After spending 3 hours I've gone from thinking this game was at best a 2/10 to not even being worth the $2 I spent on it during a sale. I've gone from hoping the company continues making games (because I really like the genre) but focus more on story, to hoping they never attempt another RPG again.In short, not only can I not recommend the game, I strongly advise people to stay away from it even if they offer if for 90% off. Hell I wouldn't even suggest people get it if it becomes free, because it's not worth the memory even if you have 4TB of free space left.

Lots of back tracking and figuring out routes.  Combat is hard and there is lots of it once you start to explore the world map and lots of grinding for experience. Game has a tendency to show you that you just took a wrong turn by sending unbeatable monsters in your way.  Many monsters will hit you with status attacks and kill you. It also goes the other way around and this makes combat one of the better designed feature in the game. Abilities are learned with 'cues' that are scattered around the map. Books can be found during the travels that explain the story. Pretty straightforward actually. I am really on the fence with this game. It is a new kind of blast from the past with a hardcore heart built on a old game engine. Buyer beware. Look closely to what you are about to buy before getting this. There is nothing casual about this title so prepare for a tough adventure where no one holds your hand and tells what to do.

-Quick Review-Labyronia RPG was developed by Labyrinthine and released in 2015. As it's name suggests: Labyronia is an RPG. being an RPG there are many common themes that you experience in this genre of games: Emphasis on story, monster grinding, and gear juggling.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You play as Arres, a particularly gifted Mage and student of Ibiz, you start your quest in an isolated shanty, and very little explanation on what to do. Like many classic RPG's you don't start out knowing what your goal is, you need to systematically talk to everyone and eventually come across the objective.Sure, the “About this game” text give some incite into what the objective is, but when you actually start playing you need to stumble and explore your way to each area. The only way I figured out where to go next, is if one place 1-shots me, then I guess that's not the next area to go. (rocket science... i know)An update... of sorts...About 10 hours into the game suddenly interesting things started to happen and I started to become invested in the story, consider this an "updated" section of the guide; I became quite interested in Arres, and the enemies he encountered. It turns out there is more to the story then I had realized!Gameplay: Labyronia RPG boasts on 6 key features:1) “non-linear progression”Well in a literal sense there is some sense of exploration, but as I said earlier, it was pretty clear to me when I was in the wrong area: I would be defeated in 1 hit.2) “Cue system to encourage exploration”Not really, if you play RPG's you speak to everyone anyway, and anytime you see some strange structure you're going to check it out in case it progresses the story. I would disagree with this point, the Cue system could be replaced with any reward.3) “Strategic Boss battles, and smooth combat system”I would disagree with this feature, while the combat is very minimalist, there are some key points that you need to learn about within the game, specifically: different armor increases different stats, sometimes you need to equip a higher magic defense item, over a better general-defense-item.(Call me an idiot, but in almost every other game ever made, the more green numbers the better the armor is... not the armor that spikes one stat.)4) “Random Battles are only on the world map”Thank god, more RPG's need to do this. The down side is that you need to leave and reenter area's to grind, but I'm not complaining! I'd rather have the chance to sneak by an encounter.5) “Clean, colorful visuals”Well that's a fair description... but I'm not the kind of person who cares about graphics, I could play a game which only has text... if it was well written I could enjoy it too.6) “Experience the emotional storyline and challenge the four elemental gods”Well, I haven't felt emotionally moved by these characters because you don't really learn more about Arres, he's almost a silent protagonist... he does occasionally speak when progressing in the story, but at least half way through the game I don't really have a sentimental connection to this world, or the story.update after 10 hours:It gets better! but you gotta keep going for it to get interesting...Achievements: Labyronia RPG has six achievements, the easiest to earn are the first three. The first achievement (Welcome to the world!) you earn just by starting the game. The second (Unknown Explorer) is earned if you stumble into the forest early... which you probably will, you'll do it sooner or later. The third achievement you'll earn by wandering around and speaking to everyone in the game, you'll eventually come across a random bar and see a poor fellow in the corner by himself. The last three achievements are unlocked much later in the game.Price: Labyronia RPG is priced at $2.99, while I won't say 'this game is the most fun RPG I've ever played', it passes my price-value-system, for every dollar spent I want to spend at least an hour playing the game.Conclusion: To recap: The story was so-so, not very memorable. The gameplay is on par for most RPG's, but not very engaging. The achievements aren't over done, but do require beating the game. The Price is very fair for the game released.I can recommend this game to anyone who wants to play an RPG which is easier on your computer graphic's card and CPU, doesn't mind experience grinding, looking for some challenge and learning new-ish mechanics.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update November 15, 2015:For some strange reason I could post "test", but not my whole review, so I just posted test and pasted my review in its place.Edit/Update August 15, 2016:Click here to check out my Labyronia RPG 2 review[/url

												If you like old school RPGs this is a well-designed one for a RPGMaker game.  The story is reminiscent of when we had to defeat elemental lords of water, fire, earth and air to beat the earlier Final Fantasy games, although it is a bit simpler than any of the classic RPGs.  That's okay, though, if you're just playing this game to kill some time.  It does a good job of that - expect to spend at least 20 hours in finishing this game.Game progression can also be pretty non-linear, meaning I had to figure out how I would like to proceed - and there were enough options to make the game more interesting than most of your cookie-cutter RPGs out there.  It was easy to miss something important and a lot of backtracking might have to be made.  If you're very thorough with exploring, it will pay off, though.  And if you miss something, you might come back much stronger, making backtracking that much easier to do.  I was especially satisfied with how I came back to one particular area - the Deep Grotto - and was able to handily beat a mob that I couldn't the first time I went through it.The story itself is linear, though - your actions won't change how the game ultimately plays out.  The puzzles are somewhat challenging but not overly frustrating if you have a good memory and pay attention to what you're doing.  There are some key items you absolutely need to make any progress at all, however.  The pickaxe is especially important and you will always have occasion to look for a way to use it.  The labyrinths are only frustrating if you keep forgetting the way to go.  The enemies have vulnerabilities you have to learn how to exploit.  You also have to learn new abilities from finding "cues" which can be anything from a statue to an animal, as well, so keeping an eye out for anything unusual is important.  Learning what gear can be best for specific battles is also useful in many different situations.Dialogue was pretty well done, although I had to chuckle at some of the text in the books that you read in the game - one called a historical decision "ret..arded" for example, not exactly what you'd expect in the lore of a fantasy game.  A blossoming romance in the game also felt unnecessarily forced.  Forming an actual party actually doesn't happen until much later in the game which I felt like was something that could have been done sooner.  That being said, the game is very fun to play for old school RPGers and I recommend it if you like that type of game.

I got this game in a bundle for what amounts to 18 cents, so I'll keep it and come back eventually to see if I can make it to the end, but I can't recommend it. 												Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Labyronia RPG with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.       Before I even began playing, I already had a gripe: Labyronia was not built for HD. Yes, I know that the art style mimics that of old SNES RPGs but that is no excuse for looking absolutely janky when in fullscreen. Following up the poor initial presentation was a story that was... cheesy? I find it difficult to accurately describe it. There are Gods who have a super power ancient artifact, non-gods are at war with them, non-gods lose and the world is fractured into X number of factions/regions, etc. It’s not quite “cookie-cutter” but very generic for these types of games.       Speaking of broad stereotyping of RPG maker games, the opening scene-as if following the cliche template bullet for bullet-begins with you waking up in your bedroom. At least others give some quasi-convincing exposition for why you of all the inhabitants of the world are going to begin a journey to defeat the prior specified evil. Labyronia opens with “Time to fight this evil, which I am qualified to do because I have magic and skills. Let me get my sword out of the chest.” I don’t think a game has ever motivated me less.       So what was my gameplay experience like? I wandered around the room and clicked on things (like you do) bringing me to the first straw: the default key binding for interacting with anything is O (B for 360 pads). Yes this is a almost pointless gripe, but I was curled up and comfy in bed with no desire to get up to the keyboard to remap it. I sucked it up and headed out side, using the button ubiquitously responsible for cancel/escape to talk to people. In the process I managed to open my inventory, a critical RPG feature which I have no idea how to access since the only button pressed thus far has been O/B. This led to the acquisition of straw number two. I got out of bed determined to figure out all the buttons once and for all via the F1 menu. This was the most horrendous mapping interface I have ever seen; gamepad buttons were mapped to random letters with no explanation as to what they actually did. I couldn’t be bothered to decrypt this menu so I returned to the game for the final straw. I COULD NOT leave the inventory screen. For those who are thinking “Oh, you just don’t have the button mapped to the controller correctly”, you’re right. Do you know where else it wasn’t mapped? ANYWHERE. I pushed every-and I do mean every- button on the keyboard and mouse and nothing did more than give me a rude buzzer.        RPG Maker shovel-ware is a dime a dozen (often literally) and unless you offer something mindblowing out of the gate, any small flaw or defect can become a dealbreaker. I have a key for Labyronia RPG 2 which is next on my roster; here’s hoping they have polished it up considerably.

												For costing just a few bucks, this game was pretty good. An ambitious setting, solid combat, and unique mechanics kept me playing even when the puzzles had me flustered.You can tell the creators spent a lot of time dreaming up the world of Labyronia, with a history of war, magic, gods, and monsters to discover as you play. Some details seem superfluous, while you may want to keep others in mind if you want to progress. Talk to every NPC, read every book, and examine everything that looks even slightly out of place. You'll find that rewards await the diligent investigator in the form of quest items, spells and abilities, and treasure.The combat is simple enough, with most enemies sporting elemental weaknesses that you find by setting them on fire and such. There is a difficulty curve that can be quite steep if you don't take some time to grind a level here and there. The acquisition of the second and third party members is relatively close together fairly late in the game, which trivialized several battles but made up for it near the end of the game, when combining abilities is almost essential to prevail.Cues are in-game locations and objects that serve as skill books, with each cue teaching a spell or ability to a certain party member. Keep each cue you find in mind, as you may not be able to use it the first time you run across it. Some are for abilities you might never use, but others are pretty much required to beat the game. With a wealth of items and several tiers of gear, you'll upgrade at a nice pace. Since the best gear is found in the world and money isn't really ever an issue past the beginning, it's easy enough to dilute the difficulty by buying stacks of health potions and revives and whittling away at stronger enemies while chugging healing drinks.The puzzles ranged in difficulty from "that was a puzzle?" to "there is no way this is a puzzle, the game must be broken," and I had to look up the solution once or twice because I'm bad and I should feel bad. But you shouldn't feel bad if you have to. As you may have guessed from the name, there are several labyrinths involved in this game. Another, less obvious theme is that of fractals. These two concepts serve as the foundation for the design and aesthetic of the world, for better or worse. You'll wind your way through a labyrinth, spot that chest sitting just out of reach on another spur of land, and wonder where you had to turn three intersections back to get to it. Likewise, you'll wonder what lay in the center of this strange pattern of terrain and go back and forth to find an entrance and wriggle your way through, usually to a prize.A few of my gripes were that some areas were just too big, with a lot of empty space you have to run through, usually while you're backtracking from a dead end. All of the quest items are only used once to get past a specific obstacle, which was a bummer for me at first. After getting these shoes that let me walk on lily pads, you think I would be able to walk across all the lily pads, and not just the one floating in front of the door of a shrine I need to burglarize. Many puzzles could have easiliy incorporated elements that would put these items to use so that when you find one it doesn't just get used once and lay forgotten in the key items tab of your inventory. Even some of the usable items were literally useless, except to provide flavor. I thought that maybe this drakna cigar or whatever might have a use somewhere down the line, perhaps to trade with an NPC, but apparently it's just for when the hero gets to jonesing for a smoke. Sure, it probably restores some (of what replaces) mana, but I never noticed. It's the same sort of thing with several other items. At the end of the day, all you need are the potions that fullly restore health, the ones for mana, and the revive items once you get party members.Labyronia is a great game, especially considering the price. If you can get it on sale, even better. It's several hours of puzzling, fighting, and storytelling on par with a more expensive game, with just a few drawbacks to test your patience.

												After I bought "Legend of Mysteria RPG" which is developed by the same guy(s) I knew that this game and the sequel are going to be epic. So I waited for a sale and bought them both. These are the best 24 cents I've ever spent for a game (48 for the 2 of them). I got "Legend of Mysteria RPG" in a bundle for maybe 10-15 cents. Now, just because they are cheap doesn't mean they are bad. Personally I had a great time playing them. I will focus on reviewing my experience in "Labyronia RPG".It's an RPG game (obviously) so that's a plus (for me at least). You fight monsters and bosses, get gold, eat food to regenerate hp or use spells to do that, gain xp, buy a lot of things, explore the map, collect key items, level up, collect cues to learn new spells. I love all of that!I've followed two guides to complete the game. Yes, I died a lot of times and spent time wandering but my point is that it's not a short game.The music is good (not irritating). At different areas it changes. I enjoyed one particular track and the rest were ok.There are many characters, few of which are the main ones. Most of the game you will fight monsters with a single character. At about mid game one more character joins you and then another. The more, the merrier, right? It turns out that "Legend of Mysteria RPG" is connected to "Labyronia RPG". I mean, in the latter I've been to a place that I'd already visited in the former. However there were still a lot of new areas to explore and that's always been fun. Speaking of which, the map is huge. There are a lot of places to visit and it takes time to do so (I am not complaining). When you are at end game it's a lot easier to travel.The only drawback is that the game crashed twice. But I played it for 15 and a half hours so I can't complain. You have 16 save slots so save often.There are achievements, all of which can be unlocked (I did that) and there are also trading cards (I don't care about them).So for this price it's a must-buy. It's ridiculously cheap if you ask me. I've played tons of games which were more expensive and I didn't enjoy some of them as much as I enjoyed "Labyronia RPG". Can't wait to play the sequel. Great game for a great price. The "Add to Cart" button is waiting for you to click it. Don't hesitate and do that.

												Story: 2/10Gameplay: 3/10Environments: 3/10Despite my negative review, I did have a pretty fun time playing this game. I actually recommend it if it is on sale and if you are willing to put some time into it. There are far, far better RPGs out there, though.StoryAfter the brief intro scene fades out, the main character awakens and for some reason decides that it is time to finally do his part in trying to save Labyronia. That's all the game really gives you to begin the game with, and it makes a bit of a habit out of leaving the player in the dark about what exactly you are supposed to be doing. For the majority of the game the only real information you learn about the world and plot comes from books and notes that you can read and are almost entirely optional. The story only really begins once you have obtained the fire crystal, the third out of four, which is perhaps more than four hours into the game depending on how lost you get in each area. Up to that point you are mostly going around looking for a way to obtain the crystalss and trying to see what areas you can access without dying to enemies. Once the story starts, though, it proves to be both basic and pretty lackluster, especially the sudden romance that occurs between the main character and an eventual party member. There is nothing especially memorable about any of the dialogue in this game; despite playing it to it's completion just the other day I don't even remember if it was really poorly written or not, which may or may not be a plus. It was nice to learn about the characters and the world, but there really isn't much to it all.GameplayGeneral:Regarding the shops in this game, they all seemed to contain pretty balanced items for the area, though I found it strange that so much armor was available for party members you wouldn't even have for a number of hours yet. Sometimes newer shops would even have better alternatives, so there would be no point to going back for the older variants when you could make use of them.As far as consumables go, you can access the Witch's shop very early on in the game, perhaps even before the first boss if you are careful, and it sells full HP potions and full AP potions that are considerably cheaper than a lot of healing items that are not as effective. What's more is that in the area around the Witch's shop are enemies that drop an absolute fortune compared to other monsters and they are only ever fought one at a time. Of course, you can't even dream of fighting them early on in the game, but I found myself heading back to the Witch whenever I needed to stockpile potions.Exploring:Wandering around the overworld was very tedious for the vast majority of the game. In towns and dungeons and such you can move quite a bit faster, but the overworld does not have an equivalent to the "Dash" option. I think it wouldn't have been so bad if there had been no chance to encounter enemies in the overworld, especially since the majority of encounters in the game already do not occur in the overworld. Nearer to the end of the game, travel becomes incredibly simple and actually pretty fun, but you have to put up with a lot of trudging around back and forth the world map a couple times to get that far.One of my least favorite aspects of this game is exploring wide open areas. The labyrinths honestly aren't so bad on their own, but the worst part is that there is no map system (save for a place where it was still very possible to get lost even when you know where you are wanting to go). If there were a map that the main character filled out as you explored allowing for easy back-tracking, the labyrinths would have been a lot less of a pain to navigate, but the real pain comes from exploring areas that wrap around (once you go all the way right you end up on the very left, etc) with items in specific places that are required to progress in the game. I recall at least two areas like that in the game, and they both took me a absolutely boring amount of time to completely traverse.One thing I actually really liked about this game was the Cue system. Scattered around the map are interactable objects that your characters can learn new skills from, provided they are in your party. This reminded me a lot of the way you obtained new Effects in Yume Nikki, and it was actually pretty fun to see what skill each Cue was going to give the characters. Unfortunately, a number of these skills are pretty boring or useless and you have to backtrack quite a lot for them once you finally have your other party members. Most of the back-tracking for Cues isn't so bad, but, once again, the wide open areas are a nightmare for finding specific things.Battles:The combat system is very basic in this game which I find to be more of a positive than a negative in this case. However, I was many hours into the game before I accidentally stumbled accross the option to flee battles as there is no indication that you can do so whatsoever. The balancing could have used a lot of work, too; sometimes you can be strolling along defeating enemies with ease and then you can run into an enemy that has the ability to Confuse or Ground you repeatedly, both of which have a chance to render you unable to fight until you die. This is perhaps most apparent in the boss fight for the earth crystal, because if you don't have resistance to Grounding, this is exactly what will kill you over and over again. That's not even what makes this fight so memorable; you'll have to backtrack all the way across the map to purchase an item that gives you that resistance before heading all the way back for the crystal. However, this very same tactic can be used against enemies once you obtain abilities that have a chance to stun, though the game unfortunately does not tell you when an enemy is immune to certain status effects.For the most part, it isn't too difficult to tell when you are powerful enough to be in a new area and as you progress you should find that the majority of enemies (including bosses!) are forgettable and pretty easy to beat. This becomes far more obvious when you finally gain party members, which makes all the battles in the game tremendously simple, especially when you discover a certain skill for the archer; out of all the skills I collected, the second best for the archer attacked three times and had a chance to hit each enemy in the battle, whereas the best skill attacked every single enemy you were fighting six times each.The final point I would like to make regarding the battle system is that the "twist" for the final boss irritated me more than anything. It's pretty hard to mention without spoiling what happens, but it basically forces you, without warning, to change your play style right as you face the most difficult battle of the game. In any case, once you've figured out the patterns and how much better flat out resistance is over defense points it becomes pretty simple as well.EnvironmentsI had no issues with most of the art, but apparently a lot of the assets in this game are just RPG Maker assets, and a lot of the monsters looked odd or almost out of place because of this. I had no issues with the music or sound effects. The music was actually pretty nice, but, again, it wasn't particularly memorable. Very few of the characters in this game felt like more than a standard npc, and some of the character portraits looked a bit strange.As far as level design goes, a lot of the game was pretty okay without being terribly original, but there was one labyrinth at the least that I specifically recall disliking, and it was the one where you get the air crystal. Even now I'm not entirely sure how it works, but I assume that it was teleporting me around at random. After clearing it, I just kept walking up to teleporters until I found my way to the end, which left a bad taste in my mouth.

												The story and setting are uninspired and underdeveloped. You are given a task and that's what you get. You can find some lore books to read that attempt to flesh out the world like what has been seen in the Elder Scrolls series, but there is nothing within the game to connect that lore, so it doesn't even matter and isn't worth the time. Characters don't develop, plot doesn't develop it just advances on its own as you go forth, and the dialog is stale.In terms of gameplay, it is the barebone standard of turn-based RPGs.  Having one character for more than half the game makes some status effects game ending cheap shots. Instead of having magic be a level-based unlock, there is a gimmicky cue system where you must find strange things in your environment to interact with to learn new spells. It is very unnecessary and a pain when new party members finally join for you will be off backtracking to all the areas you visited that had cues you couldn't use. Considering each area is rather small and cues being blatantly obvious, what little exploration is there is forced and uninteresting. The graphics and sound are fine for what they are and I love pixel art, especially where RPGs are concerned. I don't personally care about stock assets considering the price of the game is so low; I understand not everyone is a born Edward Hopper. I'm more interested in plot and setting in these regards and that is where the game ultimately failed for me.Labyronia doesn't feel like a polished game. It seems like a good start to a campaign, despite the formulaic premise, but lacks any real meat to make you care about anything to keep pressing on, despite the short game length. It's too bare-boned and lifeless as a whole for me to regard it in a positive light.

												I'm a person that loves RPG Maker games; my avatar's the Batter from OFF, for crying out loud. I enjoy going on rpgmaker.net and seeing the things that some people can make. A lot of people stereotype RPG Maker games to be low effort when there's just as many games that have care put into them, with original graphics and everything.But this game - and all other games by the creator - symbolizes that stereotype.Labryonia just seems to use the default assets provided by the RPG Maker VX Ace engine along with some resources that seem to be pulled from resource packs. The only original things seem to be those book pages you find lying around every now and then, but even then they all just seem like text pasted onto a page template. As for the story, it's pretty much humdrum elemental stuff. If you're in for an incredibly basic JRPG experience, sure, it's fine, but as some games like To the Moon demonstrates, RPG Maker could be used to tell incredible stories, and sadly Labryonia is as bland as it is uninspired.My play time looks short, yes, but the beginning parts of the game looks like an omen of mediocrity to come. Allow me to rant. The first, real dungeon of the game is the Water Labyrinth. The first dungeon of a game should be easy and interesting (though not overly interesting - the real fascinating stuff should be saved for toward the end), but this dungeon is neither. It's like the Hell Maze from Yume Nikki except somehow worse, and it's real easy to get lost an/or hit dead-ends. The whole dungeon is blue. It's an eyesore. There is little varience in dungeon design as well, save for the occasional red crystal. See, you're supposed to find all these red crystals to open the door to the boss... but of course these crystals are hidden all throughout the dungeon so you'll be stuck with the tedious and eye-killing task of walking around the badly designed dungeon. There are two reprieves though, I'll have to admit. Thankfully encounters in dungeons are on-screen and not random encounters; if they were, I would have dropped the game right then and there. Secondly, there is an item that gives you regenerating AP (the game's version of MP), so you'll be able to heal off any damage you take. If you're sincerely playing this game, I recommend picking this up. Meanwhile, the actual boss fight is manageable - if extremely tedious like everything else.Now that is not a good way to start a game off. Games should ease you into the experience, not bore or frustrate you into senselessness, but Labryonia did just that. I'm honestly shocked that this game has such a good rating on Steam. If rpgmaker.net had more users and momentum, I'm sure that the game would have gotten completely savaged like most other low-effort works. In all honesty, the only reason why I picked this and the second game up is because it was dirt cheap and I'm a sucker for easy Steam cards.Do you want a good RPG Maker game? This is not one. I recommend going on RPG Maker sites and poking around for anything good. I personally recommend Grist of Flies and HOME if you're looking for anything recent-ish. Want to throw your money at an RPG Maker game? Why not give Lisa: The Painful RPG and To the Moon a go instead of this?But then again, this game is dirt cheap, so why not?(If there is one thing to praise about this game though, I like the idea of gaining skills from certain sources. If this was a good game this would push the player to explore, providing incentive beyond a chest full of gold or items. Too bad this isn't a good game.)

												FIRST, while the game is inspired by FF and CT, by no means is it the same as them. Labyronia brings to the table a unique fighting fantasy game which is both challenging and exciting.I made the mistake of thinkining that this was one of those games which you could finish in a single sitting.. THE JOKE WAS ON ME. You cannot finish this game in a single sitting and you WILL BE FRUSTRATED at several intersections while you try to figure out where to go and what to do (although that shouldn't take you very long).ANYWAY, there is much that I say about this game, lets begin:The game in itself has a wonderful storyline with a fantastic way of slowly revealing bits of information to keep the player engaged. If you're into mysteries, this game will keep you on the edge of your seat, determined to find out just why the hell you're doing what you are. DID I MENTION THAT THERE ARE FLASHBACKS? FLASHBACKS!While the game doesn't feature the baddies health or level meters, the game does give you a fair amount of warning if a creature is too powerful for you to handle at that moment and lets you decently level up as you progress through the game. I doubt you'll need to grind through this game (unless you've been skimping out on all those encounters!). Also, the game warns you when you have to fight bosses and there's usually always a save point somewhere nearby that you can use. Its safe to say that if you spot a save point, you're probably going to need it so make sure to save up.Speaking of which, the battle style is incredibly simple. You don't have a 'battle meter' in the game so your turns are mostly based on your Agility levels. YEAH, GO BACK TO THOSE GAMES WHERE YOU HAD TO PREP YOUR CHARACTERS STAT POINTS.The game isn't as open world as it may seem at first, there are fixed boundries that loop as you pass through, AND THERE ARE NO GUIDE MAPS OR SIGNIFICANT MARKED LOCATIONS, which makes areas really seem as a Labyrinth. However, it doesn't take very long (unless you have the memory of a goldfish like I do) to figure out the layout of the area once you're in there (except for that Desert of Illusions. WHAT A ♥♥♥♥♥).ITEMS. While you may think that the game lacks items and armory, I found whatever available to be sufficient for the gameplay. Also, in Labyronia, don't sell all the weapons and armour just because you think you're not going to need them, some of those items have special properties which you're going to seriously need later on.. UNLESS YOU GRINDED TO A SUPER HIGH LEVEL.There is still so much more I could say about this game, BUT I WON'T. I don't want to ruin the excitement and fun out of the game so just purchase is and play it. Its worth a lot more than the price you're paying for it.

												I'm a fan of RPG and the description of this game said it was heavily inspired by 3 similarly amazing games. So, decided to try this and yes, I've had moments where I enjoyed it (story mostly) and moments where I hated it (ugh).To begin, the story starts off very mysteriously and nearing the very end, you find out what goes on. It does have a story, but it is not as story rich as one hoped. In fact, not much of a story going on until you encounter the new party members, whom joins you near the end of the game.  Yes, I don't understand why the game was developed in this manner, but oh well. The game mechanics are pretty much turn and agility based. Characters take turns to perform an action and whomever has the higher agility goes first. Soundtrack is nice and kept me entertained during gameplay (all ~10 hrs of it). Not a bad soundtrack overall. Graphics are as mostly decent for an RPG 2D game. Some monsters did appear very pixelated, which I'm not sure if that was intended or not. One big concept with graphics is that most cue items are differently designed to have their graphics be different than a 'normal' object. This and the golden circles for important info in the game are highlighted and should be commended. Otherwise, you will be stuck clicking on many items throughout the game (or just miss it all haha).Past all that comes the downside of this game. When you begin the game, there is absolutely no sense of direction of where to go. No 'navigation' and you can honestly wander off to do something completely out of order. While what you can or cannot do is limited, you can easily frustrate yourself by doing something out of order and have to backtrack. I got lucky and I believe I went in a pretty much correct order, but I can see someone else playing and screwing up at the beginning, because they chose differently. Next, the concept of a looping map is very cool, but not enjoyable. In Alathar and the Desert of Illusions, the maps are gigantic and much larger than I honestly think they should be. You can easily wander the map for an hour or two and just starting to understand where anything is at before you can progress to the next part in the game. It was at this point I had to refer to a guide to even progress, because I spent quite awhile trying to locate what I needed to get to progress in the game. Again, lack of direction/navigation from the game. This is especially true if you stop playing the game and come back to it, you probably won't recall where you left off or what to do next. Another mechanic of the game where I think needs improvement, is that once you have access to Artemis and you have free reign of the world, you really need to keep the airship closeby and remember to go back to it. IE: I went to the desert and went through it all to the other side. Learned the hard way that Artemis remains where you left it (facepalm). Lastly, the concept of money and items throughout the game. At the beginning of the game, I tried to pinch every piece of gold and didn't purchase the most 'powerful' items at the time. If you have played other RPGs, you may have developed a habit hoarding and pinching your resources habit. In this game, not so much of an issue. If you do run out of gold, go fight a few monsters and you will earn it back easily. If you aren't strong enough, wait a little bit and explore the section of where you are and look for the chests. They will most likely yield items for you to be stronger/strong enough to pass through this section and a little bit in the next. So most items aren't necessary until the final section of the game. However, at that point, money is everywhere and you can easily amass it via grinding on some monsters (werewolves are nice, but there are those carnivorous trolls, which are definitely the best!). Some items just come too late in the game too. IE: Crown of Ely, flower that revives you with 50% HP, rings that boost elemental defense. If they came up earlier in the game, it would've been more enjoyable and it could've been a reason to make certain enemies stronger.  Overall, still a fun RPG game to play. I can see someone rushing past the whole game in about half the time I played. I took my time and tried to not refer to the guide as much as possible for about the first half of the game. If you don't have a guide, I think you are looking at 15+ hours of trying to figure everything out. With the guide, straight to finish, probably 5-6hrs. Definitely some issues/flaws in this game, but still enjoyable to play. 7.5/10.

												I'm a fan of RPG and the description of this game said it was heavily inspired by 3 similarly amazing games. So, decided to try this and yes, I've had moments where I enjoyed it (story mostly) and moments where I hated it (ugh).To begin, the story starts off very mysteriously and nearing the very end, you find out what goes on. It does have a story, but it is not as story rich as one hoped. In fact, not much of a story going on until you encounter the new party members, whom joins you near the end of the game.  Yes, I don't understand why the game was developed in this manner, but oh well. The game mechanics are pretty much turn and agility based. Characters take turns to perform an action and whomever has the higher agility goes first. Soundtrack is nice and kept me entertained during gameplay (all ~10 hrs of it). Not a bad soundtrack overall. Graphics are as mostly decent for an RPG 2D game. Some monsters did appear very pixelated, which I'm not sure if that was intended or not. One big concept with graphics is that most cue items are differently designed to have their graphics be different than a 'normal' object. This and the golden circles for important info in the game are highlighted and should be commended. Otherwise, you will be stuck clicking on many items throughout the game (or just miss it all haha).Past all that comes the downside of this game. When you begin the game, there is absolutely no sense of direction of where to go. No 'navigation' and you can honestly wander off to do something completely out of order. While what you can or cannot do is limited, you can easily frustrate yourself by doing something out of order and have to backtrack. I got lucky and I believe I went in a pretty much correct order, but I can see someone else playing and screwing up at the beginning, because they chose differently. Next, the concept of a looping map is very cool, but not enjoyable. In Alathar and the Desert of Illusions, the maps are gigantic and much larger than I honestly think they should be. You can easily wander the map for an hour or two and just starting to understand where anything is at before you can progress to the next part in the game. It was at this point I had to refer to a guide to even progress, because I spent quite awhile trying to locate what I needed to get to progress in the game. Again, lack of direction/navigation from the game. This is especially true if you stop playing the game and come back to it, you probably won't recall where you left off or what to do next. Another mechanic of the game where I think needs improvement, is that once you have access to Artemis and you have free reign of the world, you really need to keep the airship closeby and remember to go back to it. IE: I went to the desert and went through it all to the other side. Learned the hard way that Artemis remains where you left it (facepalm). Lastly, the concept of money and items throughout the game. At the beginning of the game, I tried to pinch every piece of gold and didn't purchase the most 'powerful' items at the time. If you have played other RPGs, you may have developed a habit hoarding and pinching your resources habit. In this game, not so much of an issue. If you do run out of gold, go fight a few monsters and you will earn it back easily. If you aren't strong enough, wait a little bit and explore the section of where you are and look for the chests. They will most likely yield items for you to be stronger/strong enough to pass through this section and a little bit in the next. So most items aren't necessary until the final section of the game. However, at that point, money is everywhere and you can easily amass it via grinding on some monsters (werewolves are nice, but there are those carnivorous trolls, which are definitely the best!). Some items just come too late in the game too. IE: Crown of Ely, flower that revives you with 50% HP, rings that boost elemental defense. If they came up earlier in the game, it would've been more enjoyable and it could've been a reason to make certain enemies stronger.  Overall, still a fun RPG game to play. I can see someone rushing past the whole game in about half the time I played. I took my time and tried to not refer to the guide as much as possible for about the first half of the game. If you don't have a guide, I think you are looking at 15+ hours of trying to figure everything out. With the guide, straight to finish, probably 5-6hrs. Definitely some issues/flaws in this game, but still enjoyable to play. 7.5/10.

												So like others before have stated, I wanted to like this game. I really did, but there were far too many cons in just over an hour of playtime that gradually depleted that hope until all I was left with was a game over screen screen prompting me to return to the source and try my luck again, which unfortunately, you will be needing a lot of if you attempt to play this game. First I will start with the pros that I found.+ The sounds and music are very well done, and are reminiscent to Secret of Mana in regards to music quality and Final Fantasy: Mystic Quest in regards to the sound effects, especially your sword attack.+ When you talk to some NPCs they show a small character profile of them which is very well drawn.+ The first and only village I visited, which while small, was well drawn out and I liked seeing some of the animations, including the flowers blowing in the wind, and the birds and butterflies moving around. It definitely added a bit of charm to the otherwise static world.Now I have to move on to the cons and before anybody chooses to downvote my review, please take into account that this is my opinion.- When I booted up the game it started off in a small (Minesweeper) size window that was hard to see, so I found the option to move it into fullscreen which upgraded the screen size about 1/3 more which wasn't much better but it at least made it viewable. Unfortunately, while playing, the screen constantly flickered and glitched while I moved slowly, I might add around the overworld, which after a few minutes began to hurt my eyes. There is an option in the settings where you can decrease the flickering, but after clicking it, it didn't do much to help.- My character moves as slow as a snail in the overworld map to the point where I would pray that I wouldn't encounter an enemy while I could see the lone village at the edge of my screen. Although, his pace quickly changes in specific area screens with the click of the Shift button making it more bearable, but still making me dread trudging once again around the overworld.- The first battle I had after leaving my house was with a Python enemy, and so I thought I got this, but was sorely mistaken after getting knocked out from three hits without even the knowledge of knowing how much damage I inflicted on it. No enemy health bars makes the battles annoying to the point where I had to keep track of how much health each of the six enemy types I encountered had in my head and relied once again on luck to strike back with the correct amount of damage in the fewest amount of turns.- No item drops, only gold which becomes pointless after a short while due to no variance in weapons, armor or items available in the first town. How can the Wool Robe be worth more MDG (Whatever that is) that the Leather Tunic and the tunic only increases your defense by 2 points? Really? How does that make sense?- I must have crossed the first bridge at least thirty times farming for experience, which you will need to do right off the bat, trust me, and no matter how fast I was, or well versed with my timing, could not sneak up on the lone enemy! Almost every RPG, especially 90's era RPGs have allowed the character/ player to sneak up and get a surprise attack, why is that not an option now?- Some of the design choices that were made baffle me, like for instance, on the first bridge, there are holes in it which reveal water beneath that is a solid blue color, like something straight out of MS Paint, but the wood paneling of the bridge is very well textured and designed. That is odd but whatever, eventually get to the Northern Bridge seperating you from the Ice World and the water surrounding the bridge is textured and even animated. Why the difference? It doesn't make any bit of sense.- What you need to be doing and where you need to go are muddled and ultimately left out for you to figure out on your own. Tried heading into the Elven forest but got sniped by the first enemy I encountered, which was an Elven Archer. Okay, let's try the Ice World, but alas, can't break rocks yet and got attacked by a gang of six ice bats all doing 30+ damage each turn which will dwindle your health pretty quickly even after reaching level 5, so I had to flee. Let's try going left towards Jenise which I figured out was the name of a city and not a woman after talking to a bald NPC in the "Cold Shoulder" Pub. Good luck trying to make it to the cave that you are supposed to travel through to the city before an Orc destroys you with their critical hits that come into play 1/2 the time. This leads me to believe that I better start grinding away or dash my chances of progressing in the game, which annoyed me further. I understand the need to grind in an RPG but make it not only fun but rewarding for the player. Take Earthbound for instance, you can beat the game at the minimum level of 40 which is nice while I could barely take down the first few enemies in this game at level 5.- The battles are completely based on luck and the games mercy at giving you a good roll of the die. This is the same for a plethora of RPGs but in this game, you merely have to spam the z button and pray that you survive, whereas in other games you can have a bit of strategy.I can go on and on and really nitpick the crap out of this but alas, I choose to forego returning to the source and ending my experience with a few closing comments.I read a review that stated this game felt like it was made in RPG Maker and I can agree wholeheartedly with that statement. Nothing felt finished, and the things that worked were overshadowed completely by the list of things that didn't. This game, is to be put bluntly, lazy and nothing more than a ploy at getting a few dollars here and there from people before getting dismissed to the bowels of Steams library. No wonder the developer is offering $300 to the first person to finish the game and send them a screenshot. It is mindnumbingly tedious and quite an endeavor to brave the rest of the game for a few hundred dollars. So in conclusion, I would not recommend this game for anyone looking to have a good time. Avoid this and go play a better game like Chrono Trigger, Earthbound, Secret of Mana, etc.2/10

												Labyronia RPG Review - Raymond KTI usually am a fan of retro RPG style games, but this one is well different to put it nicely. It's best redeeming value is that it's cheap enough that you're not throwing much away to buy it, but the simple fact of the matter is that the combat system is dull and uninteresting, and it really doesn't try to make itself worth your while. Just not much of anything there to like.  I have a lot of nostalgia for SNES era RPGs. But those games relied on their stories to make up for their lack of expressive graphics. Whereas here the art and sound are maybe the only positives for Labyronia. The music was solid. The visuals are decent. And the special effects can be quite good. But the story. The writing. The game system. The grinding. The backtracking. The mazes. All abysmal. This is what leads me to my conclusion, if you dont like classic JRPG's then dont buy this game, if you DO like classic JRPG'S still dont buy this game (not even for 29 cents) since there are RPG-Maker games out there that are tremendously better than this pile of below-mediocracy and are available FOR FREE.I would love to see the RPG-Maker-Community getting more attention, but not through meh games like this.(If you want to try a commercial one i advise you to look at To the Moon on Steam or just google one of the various Rpg-Maker-Sites for free ones)

												Very charming, short RPG. The world is small, but because of how its structured (around labyrinths!), navigating it can be puzzling, but usually in enjoyable ways. The characters aren't particularly impressive, but as this is the first game in a series, it can be expected that they will be further developed in later games. The exploration (which is almost always rewarded with rare treasures) and the lore (books to read are scattered throughout) are, in my opinion, the strengths of Labyronia. The combat isn't particularly impressive, but there are certain fights that will require strategy, usually in the form of utilizing a specific "cue," the game's version of spells/arts. Criticisms include the aforementioned lackluster character design/development, a few glitches (specific interactions with a few choice NPCs that essentially freeze the game), and the confusion that comes from navigating a few of the game's looping areas (namely Alathar and the Desert of Illusions). Eagerly anticipating the sequel, should it be released on Steam.

												Labyronia RPG is a classic turn-based RPG in the style of Chrono Trigger and the earlier Final Fantasy titles. As an RPG fan, there is little not to like in this title. There is world-adventuring, dungeon-crawling and puzzle-solving. There are small villages and larger towns, each with their own style and feel. There is lore to the game, revealed in books and scraps of paper throughout the game. Hidden in caves and dungeons all over the map are rare items and secrets, and players should take note of anything unusual they see to come back to.A fundamental aspect of the combat are Auras, derived from Cues found around the game world. An example of this might be an angry chef, who gives you the Cue for a flame attack. These Cues are scattered all over the place and serve as a fun and lasting impetus for players to really explore every nook and cranny of the world.The story is sparse and anodyne at first - stay with it. It really picks up, especially towards the end. I feel like the developers really caught the atmosphere of world-changing events well. The climactic boss battle felt grounded in the game world's events - not only difficult, but meaningful. It felt as if the outcome mattered, and the sense of reward when beating something which makes you feel that way is exactly what I play videogames for.The music was great, even the omnipresent world music I never tired of. The enemies are varied and interesting, a far cry from the re-coloured skins of Final Fantasy eg., and helped give the dungeons they inhabit their own distinct atmospheres.My only negatives with this game were as follows: the lack of direction - often I was very unsure where I was going and what to, and I could see how this might put a more casual gamer off; the confusing maps (looking at you, frozen field, forest and desert) that take far longer to traverse than should be necessary, and SPOILER  the baffling decision to only unlock your second and third party members in the last fifth of the game. Why?!  And then MEGA SPOILER  to lose the third member before the final boss battle! So you take pains to prepare, building a balanced team, only to lose a member for the duration of the fight. I laughed when it happened, it was so unexpected and silly. Some players may also have trouble with the game's difficulty, particularly at the start. All I can say is to stick with it. Longtime RPGers should have no problem, and more casual gamers will certainly find that grinding for a level or two or finding a new Cue will make once-impossible foes much more beatable.If you take the time to look past the admittedly minor problems, you will be rewarded with an entertaining, nostalgic game based around a solid combat mechanic and set in a colourful, vibrant world. I finished the game in one 12 hour playthrough and there is still more to do. For its price, Labyronia RPG is a steal and I would highly recommend you buy it.

												I have to admit I had a hard time figuring out wether I should or shouldn't recommend this game. As you can see I decided to give thumps up in the end, mostly because it's only 2,99€ (and because of the easy achievements ;) ). As a warning in advance: don't buy this game unless you are hardcore RPG gamer and don't bother JRPG stuff like grinding. Otherwise you won't enjoy it.After that's said let's talk about the game:The story takes place in Labyronia: a world filled with natural labyrinths (of course) which have been created by the four elemental gods in order to punish the humans and their rebellious wizards. And along with the labyrinths, monsters appeard throughout the lands. Yeah, this doesn't sound THAT bad. Now, 50 years after the creation of the labyrinths our main character Arres wakes up one morning and decides to finally save the world by obtaining the 4 elemental crystals and kick the gods' asses. This is were the game starts..Don't get me wrong. The story is indeed a big cliche and there are lots and lots of other issues, like when you have no exact idea what you have to do most of the time. Also the battle system seems like a let down AT FIRST. Thats just because almost every enemy can inflict fatal debuffs on you. For instance "grounded" or "stunned". While one of these debuffs is active you can't do anything until it wears off and in most causes you get killed without even landing a single hit on the enemy. What makes it worse is that you have no companions until very late in the game. Because of this you'll get killed over and over again at the beginning. But if you finally gathered some equipment that prevents certain debuffs or learned some new spells which inflict debuffs on the enemy, you can take control in most battles. This is when this game gets fun.I also like that in order to get new spells you don't have to lvl up or buy spell books at a magic store. You just have to find and interact with unique objects called "cues". This means you have to do a lot of exploring to get stronger.The dialogues are very nicely written. Nothing to complain about here. But this won't change the fact that *little spoiler* the mushy "love story" between our "hero" Arres and his companion Ann ("love at first sight" you know it..) seems extremely unreal and goofy. It made me choke. No kidding. It made me choke so hard. *little spoiler ends*The graphics, music and sounds are just RPG Maker originals. They don't look/sound bad but a bit of variety would have been appreciated..Overall it's a solid RPG Maker game. It entertains you for a few hours for little money. I kinda enjoyed it despite it's issues.

												Labyronia is surprisingly huge, and involved, for what it is -- a cheap RPG maker game. However, the length feels a little artificial to me simply because so much time is spent to walking (veeeery slowly) across the main map. Overall though it was worth the price if you have time to spare, though not groundbreaking.Cons: It's obvious early on that you're meant to gain a party, but this happens SO late in the game that it's disappointing. If you leave the game for a few days, or just don't have a great memory, it's pretty difficult to figure out what the heck you were doing; the NPCs don't often repeat plot info if you talk to them again, and you have no in-game way of checking progress. After a certain point, I also found that none of the fights were really a struggle -- I can't pinpoint why I'm feeling that, but I know especially the 'end game training area' was almost laughably easy IMO, since the fights could be won just spamming attacks, since the monsters end up doing little damage.Final con: I just didn't get that invested in the story or characters. Cut scenes could be annoyingly long, with weird long pauses that made me think the game was broken. There is a "romance" that I found just laughable.Pros: However the world is pretty big! Which I enjoyed. Which frustratingly maze-y at times, that was the point. Similarly, the lack of clear instructions (aka, closed off areas, "Go north now to do the next task!" style directions), espeically early game, I enjoyed since it felt more organic as an adventure, while there were still mechanics to more or less guide you to the right areas. The fighting was pretty well fleshed out, though nothing groundbreaking. The graphics were pretty good (except for some reason Ann's character portrait makes me think of evil dolls, idk) and the enemies were nicely varied.Bottom line, if you like explore-y (j)RPGs that let you figure things out, and have time but want to save some money, this is worth checking out.My in-game time is around 15 hours, but it would probably be a little faster for many players since I did a lot of backtracking and so on.

												2/5 Bottom line up front: Pretty enough, but quickly boring. It's a nice world with bits of lore and personality, but gameplay's core mechanic falls flat quickly. Caveats: After deciding to quit the game I checked my progress against a walkthrough. I made it a little over 2/3 of the way through completion. Maybe the game gets better during the last third.Maybe 2-3 general enemies per "area" make the battles repetitive - if not outright grindy. Combat's only saving grace is it's attack variety - though that could fall short with easily missed cues if you're less concerned about scouting literally every nook and cranny. Though they're advertised as the rewards of exploration, cues missed quickly turn to a gentle punishment, making the necessity of searching for them far less satisfying.The maze puzzles are easily solved with a follow-the-left/right wall approach (given varying amounts of time) and having to backtrack through what's already been solved in order to search for hidden goodies (that may be nothing more exciting than a limp salmon) ruins the satisfaction of their design. Worse yet, the "hints" for solving a few of the areas see-saw between being slap-in-the-face obvious or being so obscurely referenced as to be patently useless. And it's the patently useless, more often than not, that greet you in the face of true confusion. That many mazes/puzzles have clever gimmicks added to them almost makes them more disappointing.In general, the glimmering rays of effort, thought, and intelligence poured into this game are gradually dimmed and overshadowed by the repetition and monotony it gives itself over to.
